## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-06-29T15:57:46Z
## Message ID: 20230629-AL-002
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 2.0 MeV" integral electron flux remains elevated, recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-06-29T12:15Z.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels observed since 2023-06-27T12:50Z (see notification 20230627-AL-002) are likely caused by combined effects of the arrival of a CME with ID 2023-06-20T17:24:00-CME-001 (see notification 20230620-AL-003) detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-06-24T18:10Z (see notification 20230624-AL-001) and a coronal hole high speed stream starting on 2023-06-23. The maximum sustained solar wind speed at L1 reached approximately 575km/s. The solar wind speed is currently around 500km/s.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2023-06-27T12:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME update (ensemble) (STEREO A, OSIRIS-REx, Parker Solar Probe, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-06-29T11:13:16Z
## Message ID: 20230629-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

BETA PRODUCT. ENSEMBLE PRODUCT IS STILL IN DEVELOPMENT MODE. PLEASE LET US KNOW IF YOU HAVE ANY SUGGESTIONS FOR MODIFICATIONS.  

Ensemble modeling update on CME with ID 2023-06-27T20:36:00-CME-001 (see previous notification 20230628-AL-001). Based on analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric ensemble modeling carried out at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact STEREO A. For 24 ensemble members (see notes section), simulations indicate that the leading edge of the CME will reach:

- STEREO A between about 2023-06-30T10:58Z and 2023-07-01T06:07Z (average arrival 2023-06-30T20:14Z) for 83% of simulations.

Additionally the CME is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth between about 2023-06-30T16:49Z and 2023-07-01T12:52Z (average arrival 2023-07-01T02:48Z) for 79% of simulations.  The ensemble-based forecast indicates that there is a 93% chance for the maximum Kp index to be in the 3-5 range (below minor to minor).

Links to the ensemble details of the modeled event:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-06-28_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027/20230627_203600_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027_anim_tim-den.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-06-28_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027/20230627_203600_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027_arrival_Earth.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-06-28_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027/20230627_203600_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027_Earth_stack.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-06-28_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027/20230627_203600_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027_probabilistic_Kp_forecast_wdist.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-06-28_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027/20230627_203600_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027_arrival_STA.gif
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-06-28_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027/20230627_203600_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027_STA_stack.gif

## Notes:
Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

For the full details of the modeled event, please go here:
https://iswa.gsfc.nasa.gov/ENSEMBLE/2023-06-28_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027/Detailed_results_20230627_203600_ncmes1_sims24_LAHAINA027.txt

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information (CCMC DONKI)
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 21, 2023 - June 27, 2023
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-06-28T19:23:36Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2023-06-21T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2023-06-27T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20230628-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate levels during this reporting period with 7 M-class flares and 13 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-06-26T12:12Z may give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at 2023-06-30T00:00Z with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-3 (below minor) (see notification 20230627-AL-004). 

Additionally, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO imagery at 2023-06-27T20:36Z is estimated to reach NASA missions near Earth at 2023-07-01T04:55Z (plus minus 7 hours) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 4-5 (below minor to minor) (see notification 20230628-AL-001). Analysis of this event is currently ongoing.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs would impact other locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-06-21T09:48Z   Mars at 2023-06-27T00:00Z and Lucy at 2023-06-28T18:00Z (minor impacts) (see notifications 20230621-AL-001 and 20230621-AL-002)
2023-06-23T00:39Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-06-23T12:00Z and STEREO A at 2023-06-26T07:00Z (glancing blows) (see notification 20230623-AL-002)
2023-06-24T12:38Z   OSIRIS-REx at 2023-06-29T00:00Z (glancing blow)
2023-06-26T12:12Z   STEREO A at 2023-06-29T20:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230627-AL-004)
2023-06-26T15:53Z   Lucy at 2023-07-03T07:00Z (minor impact), Mars at 2023-07-01T21:09Z, and STEREO A at 2023-06-30T10:00Z (glancing blow) (see notification 20230627-AL-003)
2023-06-27T20:36Z   STEREO A at 2023-06-30T22:56Z, Parker Solar Probe at 2023-06-29T02:00Z, and OSIRIS-REx at 2023-07-02T10:00Z (see notification 20230628-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at below moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-06-25T00:00Z-03:00Z. This enhancement of geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 on 2023-06-24T18:10Z which may be associated with the arrival of a C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-06-20T17:24Z in the last reporting period (see notification 20230624-AL-001). The arrival of this CME may also have been detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments on 2023-06-24T17:45Z.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt was elevated throughout the reporting period, crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-06-23T14:10Z and again at 2023-06-27T12:50Z (see notifications 20230621-AL-003, 20230623-AL-001, 20230627-AL-001, and 20230627-AL-002). The first enhancement at 2023-06-23T14:10Z is likely associated with the effects from the coronal hole high speed stream which arrived on 2023-06-19 during the last reporting period (see notification 20230623-AL-001). The second enhancement at 2023-06-27T12:50Z is likely associated with the combined effects of the arrival of a CME with ID 2023-06-20T17:24:00-CME-001 (see notification 20230620-AL-003) detected at L1 by DSCOVR and ACE at 2023-06-24T18:10Z (see notification 20230624-AL-001) and a new coronal hole high speed stream which arrived on 2023-06-23. The maximum sustained solar wind speed at L1 reached approximately 575 km/s. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been moderate this week due to the minor geomagnetic storm and elevated energetic electron flux levels described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-06-28T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date: 2023-07-04T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary from moderate to high levels during the outlook period. There are currently eight numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13340 (currently located at N23W66) and Active Region 13341 (currently located at S15E41) produced the majority of M-class and C-class flaring during the reporting period and may continue to produce notable activity as they traverse the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13354 (N15E04) has exhibited recent growth and was recently responsible for a potentially Earth-directed CME first seen in SOHO coronagraph imagery at 2023-06-27T20:36Z. 

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low to minor storm levels during the outlook period. Barring any new Earth-directed CMEs, a CME first seen in the SOHO coronagraphs at 2023-06-27T20:36Z is expected to arrive at L1 around 2023-07-01T04:55Z and may lead to an enhancement in geomagnetic activity, possibly up to minor storm levels (see notification 20230628-AL-001). 

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Community Coordinated Modeling Center Database Of Notifications, Knowledge, Information ( CCMC DONKI )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (STEREO A, OSIRIS-REx, Parker Solar Probe, Missions Near Earth)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2023-06-28T16:45:24Z
## Message ID: 20230628-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-06-27T20:36Z.

Estimated speed: ~520 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 39 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -26/18 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-06-27T20:36:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A, as well as OSIRIS-REx and Parker Solar Probe (minor impacts).  The leading edge of the CME will reach STEREO A at 2023-06-30T22:56Z, OSIRIS-REx at 2023-07-02T10:00Z, and Parker Solar Probe at 2023-06-29T02:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may impact NASA missions near Earth: the leading edge of the CME may reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-07-01T04:55Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 4-5 (below minor to minor).
   
  
Links to the movies of the modeled event (includes CME 2023-06-27T20:36:00-CME-001):

## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2023-06-26T12:12Z.

Estimated speed: ~690 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 26 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -12/35 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates.

Activity ID: 2023-06-26T12:12:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it is estimated that this CME may affect STEREO A (glancing blow). The flank of the CME may reach STEREO A at 2023-06-29T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). 

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-3 (below minor).

The simulation also indicates that the CME may have a glancing blow at NASA missions near Earth. Simulations indicate that the flank of the CME will reach NASA missions near Earth at about 2023-06-26T12:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The roughly estimated expected range of the maximum Kp index is 2-3 (below minor).

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for June 14, 2023 - June 20, 2023
##

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at moderate to high levels during this reporting period with 1 X-class flare, 11 M-class flares, 2 O-type CMEs, and 7 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-06-20T17:24Z, associated with the X1.1 flare peaking at 2023-06-20T17:09Z from Active Region 13341 (S15E65), may give a glancing blow to NASA missions near Earth at 2023-06-24T02:00Z with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-4 (below minor) (see notification 20230620-AL-003). Analysis of this event is ongoing.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs would impact other locations:

CME Starting time  | Predicted Location/Mission Impacts (plus minus 7 hours)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
2023-06-16T11:09Z   Mars at 2023-06-22T04:00Z (minor impact) and Lucy at 2023-06-23T18:00Z (minor impact) (see notifications 20230616-AL-004 and 20230616-AL-005)
2023-06-17T10:48Z   Mars at 2023-06-23T06:00Z (minor impact) and Lucy at 2023-06-24T18:00Z (minor impact)
2023-06-20T11:48Z   Solar Orbiter at 2023-06-23T14:04Z and Parker Solar Probe at 2023-06-20T19:00Z (approximate) 
2023-06-20T17:24Z   STEREO A at 2023-06-23T19:30Z (glancing blow), Mars at 2023-06-24T23:20Z and Lucy at 2023-06-26T07:17Z (see notification 20230620-AL-003)

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6.33 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=6.33 occurred during the synoptic period 2023-06-16T03:00Z-06:00Z (see notifications 20230616-AL-001, 20230616-AL-002, and 20230616-AL-003). This enhancement of geomagnetic activity was associated with the interplanetary shock detected by ACE and DSCOVR at L1 on 2023-06-15T05:46Z caused by the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream (see notification 20230615-AL-001). The arrival of this coronal hole high speed stream was also detected by STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments on 2023-06-14.

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt remained elevated since 2023-06-17T13:35Z, most recently crossing the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-06-20T12:35Z (see notifications 20230617-AL-001, 20230617-AL-002, and 20230619-AL-001). These elevated energetic electron flux levels are likely associated with the arrival of the coronal hole high speed stream detected at L1 mentioned above. The solar wind reached a maximum sustained speed of approximately 700 km/s.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been minor to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-06-21T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-06-27T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently ten numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13341 (currently located at S15E50) produced an X1.1 flare (see notifications 20230620-AL-001 and 20230620-AL-002) and may continue to exhibit notable flaring activity during the outlook period. Additionally, Active Region 13342 (currently located at S22W81) produced a majority of the M-class flares during the reporting period and may continue to produce flaring activity before rotating off the Earth-facing disk by 2023-06-22. Finally, an unnumbered Active Region seen in STEREO A EUVI imagery near latitude N15 may rotate onto the Earth-facing disk by 2023-06-22.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to vary between minor and moderate levels during the outlook period. The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt most recently crossed the threshold of 1000 pfu at 2023-06-20T12:35Z due to the coronal hole high speed steam starting on 2023-06-15 mentioned above and will likely remain elevated during the beginning of the outlook period (see notification 20230621-AL-003). There may be additional minor enhancement in geomagnetic activity due to the arrival of the C-type CME which may impact NASA missions near Earth around 2023-06-24 (see details above).

## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period with 2 M-class flares and 7 C-type CMEs (see details below).

Based on preliminary analysis by the Moon to Mars Space Weather Analysis Office and heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center, it was estimated that the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-06-07T07:00Z would impact NASA missions near Earth at 2023-06-10T18:00Z (glancing blow) with a maximum estimated Kp index of 2-4 (below minor) and STEREO A at 2023-06-10T10:00Z (minor impact) (see notifications 20230607-AL-001 and 20230607-AL-002). The arrival of this CME may have been detected by DSCOVR and ACE at L1 around 2023-06-10T23:09Z (see notification 20230611-AL-001). STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC data may have also detected the arrival of this CME around 2023-06-10T13:20Z.

It was also estimated that the following CMEs were predicted to impact these different locations:

2023-06-13T19:24Z   Parker Solar Probe at 2023-06-14T17:11Z (see notification 20230614-AL-001)

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=2.67 for the reporting period. 

The > 2.0 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 1000 pfu for the entire reporting period.

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period.

## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-06-14T00:00Z

Solar activity is expected to vary from low to moderate levels during the outlook period. There are currently six numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. An unnumbered active region seen in SDO and STEREO A EUVI imagery near latitude S20 is expected to rotate onto the Earth-facing disk on 2023-06-15.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be at low to minor storm levels during the outlook period. An equatorial coronal hole which crossed the central meridian early on 2023-06-13 may become geoeffective on 2023-06-16, likely leading to a relatively weak enhancement in geomagnetic activity to possibly minor storm levels.

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-06-07T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-06-13T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be at moderate levels throughout the outlook period. There are currently nine numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Region 13323 (currently located at S08W22) and Active Region 13327 (currently located at S14E32) produced the majority of M and C-class flaring during the reporting period and may continue to produce notable activity as they traverse the Earth-facing disk. Additionally, there are at least two unnumbered Active Regions seen near the eastern limb in SDO imagery located around latitudes S22 and N10 which may exhibit flaring activity throughout the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be minor to moderate during the outlook period. There may be a minor enhancement in geomagnetic activity during the first half of the outlook period due to possible arrivals at L1 on 2023-06-07 and 2023-06-09 from the CMEs mentioned above. Finally, there may be additional enhancement in geomagnetic activity in the second half of the outlook period due to the possible arrival of coronal hole high speed streams from coronal holes currently centered around N20E02 and S37E12. These coronal holes may reach geoeffective longitudes on or around 2023-06-10.

This CME event (2023-06-04T10:24:00-CME-001) is also predicted to have an impact at OSIRIS-REx at 2023-06-08T00:32Z (plus minus 7 hours) based on previous heliospheric modeling (see notification 20230604-AL-001).

Ensemble CME modeling at M2M is performed by building sets of initial CME parameters and carrying out separate simulations for each set. This approach allows a mapping of initial CME parameter uncertainties into a statistical characterization of CME arrival times and impact at locations of interest.

Description of links: For each location, the first link shows the WSA-ENLIL+Cone model animation for the median CME input parameters, the second link shows the probabilistic distribution of predicted arrival times histogram, and the third link shows a stack plot of the WSA-ENLIL+Cone modeled magnetic field, velocity, density, and temperature for all ensemble members. For missions near Earth, a histogram of the probabilistic Kp forecast is also provided.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2023-05-31T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2023-06-06T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to vary from moderate to high levels during the outlook period. There are 10 numbered Active Regions on the Earth-facing disk. Active Regions 13315 (currently at S17W58) and 13312 (currently at S25W82 - now decayed to a plage) showed the highest level flaring activity during the reporting period with two lower M-class flares each. Active Region 13315 may produce additional flaring before rotating off of the Earth-facing disk by 2023-06-03. On 2023-05-31, Active Regions 13323 (S03E76) and 13319 (S18W24) produced one lower M-class flare each and may continue to display increased activity through the remainder of the outlook period.

Geomagnetic activity is expected to be minor to moderate during the outlook period due to a possible glancing blow on 2023-06-01 from the C-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-05-29T02:12Z (see details mentioned above) and the anticipated arrival around 2023-06-03 of the coronal hole high speed stream from the large southern coronal hole currently centered around S35W05. Finally, there might be a minor enhancement in geomagnetic activity in the second half of the outlook period due to a possible glancing blow on 2023-06-04 from an S-type CME first visible in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2023-05-30T17:12Z.
